content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Alone, with your friends or even with random people, this is a game you must play! Monaco was by far one of the best experencias i had this year related to videogames - counitng only to what was relesed this year -. Almost everthing is perfect on this game, from the visuals, OST and the COOP. COOP on this game is the cherry on top of the cake. Monaco has some diversity missions such as, heist, saving someone or get alive from some place. Also contains 3 game modes; Enhanced, Classic and Zombies. Enhanced is shorter, more streamlined maps and will make a better and easy experience. Classic mode that is purist, hard to say. Now to class, some to choose and they are all great. Going to give some examples, The Cleaner, he can put enemies to sleep, is really hand when you find a room full of them. The Mole, funny character to use, he can breaks for almost any room really good to dig shortcut's. I think you got the point that character in Monaco are fun and useful to use. If you ever get bored of doing COOP and SP you have two options; PVP and creation mode. PVP is here you against another player "fight" to see who stole the intel first and can escape alive. Very fun game type. The creation mode is here you can make your own levels, case you have a nice imagination you may get feature in Monaco weekly/month workshop levels. Another thing i love in games and i especially love this on in Monaco is the OST, is brilliant, this gentleman Austin Wintory[austinwintory.bandcamp.com] made an awesome job here. The OST is so calm and fits very well in this game. - I advise you hear the full ost on that site - Now that you read my shout review, go buy this game and enjoy it! Totally worth your money! ~ 8/10

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 24
												Monaco... a game I got and played with friends ages ago but didn't enjoy as much as I wish I could. As much as I thought I'd enjoy it on the outset I found the content of the game itself rather... disappointing. Let me tell you a tale:You watch the trailers, you see the tags (Like "Stealth", and "Heist"), and screenshots and you think to yourself, rightly so - "ah, this is a stealth game". You then buy the game, and as you start making your way through the game, solo or with friends, you find that that there are various mechanics that help you sneak past guards and such, and overall the ideas presented from those scenarios and abilities allow for unique ways of approaching your stealth. Then you and your friends notice the leader boards for levels... and see that the top scores... somehow managed to do it in seconds?Here is the problem: You are given all these tools, all these characters with unique designs and abilities, which altogether help to make an interesting apporach to a stealth heist. However, you then realise the following - it is much easy, efficient, and high scoring to simply run through the entire level, alerting everything as you do so, completing the objective and collecting coins and just escaping. Put simply - you are given lots of tools, but none of them are more efficient than just blitzing your way through the level.Hence, the reason why I didn't enjoy it was because it was misleading, not to say that blitzing your way through isn't fun, I kind of enjoyed it, for a while anyway. However I came to and bought this game with the intention of a stealth game. Maybe if the game atleast sort of told you that this was another way to approach then maybe it would've been fine, but with such misleading trailers and unfortunately, good and unique mechanics that are overshadowed by simply running all over the place, makes me glad I was able to refund this game.

One has the ability to put enemies to sleep for 30-60 seconds if they are not alerted. (sneak up on them). number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Summary: Heist simulator 2013Multiplayer: 4Completion: 5 hrsCards: YesCloud: YesWhen you were a kid, were you ever dragged to a social gathering and had nothing fun to do there? Monaco is the game I wish I had when I was growing up and taken to play party games with other people.In Monaco you assemble a team of specialized thieves intent on stealing goods and getting away with it. You have very limited tools to handle opposition, so you must stealth your way to the goods, grab it, and run like hell. It's pretty much as it sounds.The graphics have a rather simplistic look. They're serviceable, though the saturated palette can make it hard to see things, and is sometimes hard on the eyes. Music is also serviceable. It goes for a sort of ragtime feel, like watching a black and white film.Gameplay involves a top-down view of the area, much like looking at a blueprint, with security guards whose attention span could give MGS Genome Soldiers a run for their money. Electronic traps and security cameras also seek to alert your presence, but you can disable these should you find their terminal.If there's one thing Monaco does well, its promote teamwork. The character roles are so different and specialized that the more people you have the better your chances are of pulling this off... provided you work together.If there's one thing I would like to add to the game, it's having AI party members. I can't always get a party of four, and so I would like to have some meatshiel- I mean scapegoa- I mean accomplices to assist me in my solo capers.While Monaco isn't the kind of game I would replay for days on end, it does make a fantastic occasional party game. Sure beats playing most board games. I give Monaco a 7.5/10 Thanks spleeno!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a great multiplayer game up to 4 players, each character has a specific skill, and they need to work together to beat each level.Levels are like heists, you get in, get the valuables and get out.The graphics are retro style, in good taste and with gameplay functions in mind.The music is very good, and it draws inspiration from old piano music composed for black and white mute movies.The gameplay is where it's at, it is a lot of fun to play multiplayer with friends, public games are also fun if you are lucky and meet cool people.Playing solo is also fun but a lot harder, the game then becomes more stealthy.You can also pick up and use items like guns, bombs and tranquilizers that you may use if you're not feeling particularly stealthy, thus playing the game more like an action game.In fact you even have a bonus (unlocked from the start) Zombie mode where you are encouraged to kill the enemies.The story, while not the main attraction, will keep you entertained (should you choose to read it, since you can skip it), it contains humour and a few unexpected twists and turns.There's a lot of content, and it'll take you a while to beat it all (some of the later levels are quite hard).I recommend.

												It's an amazing game that you can play together with friends, and I've had lots of crazy antics playing in this game with my friends. It's a great game, and you just have to play it! -WesTheDerp

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Monaco is an excellent 4-player co-op game that offers a unique blend of action and puzzle solving. If you're confused by what you're seeing in the store, don't be alarmed. The screenshots and videos don't do this game justice; you have to actually play the game for a bit to get a feeling for what's going on. All that color and chaos comes together nicely when you're playing.Monaco is decent entertainment as a single-player game, but the single-player game is best used to get familiar with each character at your own speed. Where Monaco really shines is when you get 2-4 people together in co-op mode. Different characters' abilities complement each other in surprising ways, and strategies emerge that simply aren't possible in solo play. Figuring out how to combine different characters' abilities to meet the unique challenges that each level presents is half the fun. If you don't have Steam friends to play with, you'll be pleasantly surprised by the Monaco community. This is a group that really likes to cooperate, and is patient with new players. The patient, cooperative play style of Monaco appeals to more mature gamers, and the public community really reflects that.I enthusiastically recommend Monaco. It’s a blast.

												4/5More fun than a boat full of criminals.Monaco is a hide and stealth type heist game.  There are 8 characters to choose from, all with their own skills.  You spend your time sneaking around guards, hacking computers, opening vaults and stealing assets.Fun story, Lots of levels!  you can even make your own and upload them for others to play.Single player is challanging and fun.  Multi-player can range from "Epic" to "All hell has broken loose".  If you buy the game, you have to try multi-player at least once. It is so much fun, and has a great voice chat system.There is a Zombie mode as well...Monaco is one of those games I would buy for all of my friends to enjoy.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Summary: Heist simulator 2013Multiplayer: 4Completion: 5 hrsCards: YesCloud: YesWhen you were a kid, were you ever dragged to a social gathering and had nothing fun to do there? Monaco is the game I wish I had when I was growing up and taken to play party games with other people.In Monaco you assemble a team of specialized thieves intent on stealing goods and getting away with it. You have very limited tools to handle opposition, so you must stealth your way to the goods, grab it, and run like hell. It's pretty much as it sounds.The graphics have a rather simplistic look. They're serviceable, though the saturated palette can make it hard to see things, and is sometimes hard on the eyes. Music is also serviceable. It goes for a sort of ragtime feel, like watching a black and white film.Gameplay involves a top-down view of the area, much like looking at a blueprint, with security guards whose attention span could give MGS Genome Soldiers a run for their money. Electronic traps and security cameras also seek to alert your presence, but you can disable these should you find their terminal.If there's one thing Monaco does well, its promote teamwork. The character roles are so different and specialized that the more people you have the better your chances are of pulling this off... provided you work together.If there's one thing I would like to add to the game, it's having AI party members. I can't always get a party of four, and so I would like to have some meatshiel- I mean scapegoa- I mean accomplices to assist me in my solo capers.While Monaco isn't the kind of game I would replay for days on end, it does make a fantastic occasional party game. Sure beats playing most board games. I give Monaco a 7.5/10 Thanks spleeno!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Monaco ~A Short Review with no spoliers~I absolutely fell in love with this game the moment I began.The bright colors contrasted against the dark background, the fun music, and the multiplayer environment made for a terrifically fun experience.I played this game with another person,and by doing so, I feel that I got the most of the game, and thus I would recommend playing this with two or more people.Multiple playable characters, each with their own special abilities, are unlocked through a driving story line of criminal behavior -which was executed with the perfect balance of elements. This game was not as serious of a heist game as Payday 2, but it was not what I'd consider a “kiddy game”.When you assemble a team of the right characters for the mission at hand there's no way you can fail - that is unless you are me and my friends.Though you can fail multiple times, the fun never ends, at least it didn't for me. Each play through is different in itsownunique way, even though the layout of the levels is the same.Changing your characters may help if you fail a few times in a row.But when you just beat a level, it's not over. You can go back and try to “complete” the level, picking up every coin and every trophy. There's so much to do in this game, and that's why I love it.I didn't have a single complaint about the game with the catchy music and bright colors. I rate it 5/5, and recommend it to anyone who enjoys multiplayer heists.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This is my first review, and I've been a member of Steam for 4 years, so hopefully that tells you something.I bought this during the 2014 Summer sale, and have found it to be a great puzzle/heist game.Graphics:To start, if you have no desire for pixel and the retro look, then I would stop now. If you are not someone who NEEDS the incredible realism graphic engine, then you should be fine. The game gives you a couple of options for colors, but I found that the enhanced version was beautiful. The colors and shading/lighting make an awesome combination and really brings the game to life quickly. And it's not so much that it burns into your eyes either, so there's that.Audio:The music alone was awesome. I felt it was a rag-timey, pink panthery, mash up. Some of the songs had a great variation to some classic heist/jazz music that I thoroughly enjoyed. If you don't like, you can always turn off the music, but I felt it really added to the overall theme. When you almost get caught be a guard, the music changes to a faster tempo, trying to add to the suspense. It really felt more like a silent movie, where music was all you could really go off of for the tonality of the play.The sound effects were decent, there's not too much needed here.Gameplay:When I first started playing, I was lucky enough to have a few randoms in the lobby that were also new, but good spirited, so that definitely helped with the initial play through. But I will say it was a little difficult to start up and play at first, but that's my own impatience. The tutorial is actually part of the story, and if you have the patience to go and read all of it, it's actually pretty good. (I went back and read it, cause I'm typically very impatient and just want to play). Each character has their own special ability and it really does make a difference for each level. The strategy and puzzle of it comes from trying to figure out how to get by without getting caught; and if caught, trying to get away and hide. Sure, you could just run through, and try and out race the police, but the challenge is absolutely offered.  I've played with a group and solo, and found that it's WAY easier and ABSOLUTELY more fun with a group, if you can find one.All in all, I'd give the game somewhere between an 9/10. I only marked it down for two reasons: The pixel art is retro, and I get that, but a few more pixels, or less, on the police would make it more clear who they are. Could just be me, but I get a little confused about who I can and can't talk to. And (this isn't the game's fault) it's been a little difficult for me to find people to play with online.Hope this helps, happy gaming!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Superb music, vibrant colors, and superb gameplay makes Monaco one of the best indie games i've played in 2013. Multiple classes, and the ability to play as any of them to clear a level,  adds replayability as you try to beat the clock or clear all the loot on each level. Monaco's multiplayer makes it even greater. The game is hectic as everyone tries to combine their individual skills to complete the game. While it's online multiplayer isn't the liveliest, the local co-op allows your for your friends and families to easily join in the fun. In short, this game is a real gem.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Break into the building, steal the things, and get out without raising the alarm. Sounds mediocre, right? WRONG. Monaco is a fantastic game, and that fact become clear immediately upon starting up. The gameplay is much like what I just described, but with a style all its own that I cannot say I have ever seen in anything else. It's totally unique, and that style pervades every element of Monaco. The music and artwork truly shine (This is one of the few indie soundtracks that I went out and bought, to bring credence to that fact.)Alone, it's great fun, but the developers had the foresight to add in a multiplayer co-op mode- this instantly pushed a good game to great. The online chaos that may ensue, or the local co-op  madness (If you have spare controllers or keyboards) are nearly reminiscent of the great Nintendo multiplayer experiences of yore. So, if you have the money to spend, get this. You won't regret it.

												Great game! Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is one which has had me spending hours at a time beating the crap out of gendarme, smoking the heck out of innocent(but nonetheless annoying) civilians, and pushing about the mangled corpses of security guards. Monaco really allows one to explore different gameplay methods and tactics when it comes to taking on the challenges each level sets for you. Wonderful music from wonderful singers, and the art style never gets boring. Multiplayer is also excellent when playing with friends, the system is very easy to understand and use. Sadly, there are hardly any players to play with via multiplayer. Monaco has also taught me quite some bit of french. J'aime le français!8/10

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												I was part of the core group of beta testers for this game and even have my name appearing in its credits. I invested dozens of hours into the work-in-progress version of the game and thoroughly enjoyed it. The premise is theft - and you can choose from a handful of different character classes that all possess unique abilities to to pull off a successful theft (the ability to smash through walls, hack into security systems, assassinate guards, pose as guards and more). The game affords for hilarious, whimsical encounters as one progresses through a map collecting treasures that all play into a single narrative or over-arching storyline. If you are a fan of robbery/theft films and games, you'll enjoy Monaco.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												Was cool for a while. I put 15 hours into it because over the years I kept reinstalling it and having to redo all the missions. It is fun and not very hard playing alone until you get to a massive difficulty spike in the next to last thief mission where it is strikingly apparant that this game was meant to mainly be a co-op/multiplayer game. In which you won't find anyone to connect to online because it's so old, so either search the forums for someone to play with or have a friend that also has the game. Also, if you do play co-op or mp, voice chat is basically a must. Without voice communication to closely work together, it will be a mess. I mean missions are certainly doable just fine without it but the game is a much, much more fun experience if you can communicate with voice.6/10 okay for a while

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2013
												Monaco is a great looking artsy game with a great concept and, to a certain extent, this concept works out very well. More in singleplayer than multiplayer. Think of Monaco as a 1-4 player(s) Pacman-like heist game; collect as many coins as you can, grab some loot and then make a run for it. Sounds great, doesn't it ? Yes, as a concept. In reality it could've been so much better. Let me try to explain.First of all, I've been waiting for this game to be released for a long time, and now that it has finally been released I can't help but feel disappointed. Why ? Because in co-op the game is just so damn hectic and it's hard to see your location or any location for that matter. There are no instructions on how to use your character and their abilities properly. You can see why that's distracting when you're playing with other people. Your partners have certain expectations and instead of actually helping you're running around making it look like you know what you're doing. But you actually don't know. People (including yourself) will ragequit because of this. They're unforgiving. Sure, not everyone, but a lot of my games have ended that way. Also, the AI is a bit random from time to time, so there's no right way to finish a level. You need a bit of strategy and also a whole lot of luck. One thing that could instantly make this game better is by simply increasing your field of vision, giving you a better sight while walking around, and giving you more of an idea on what to do next.The single-player mode is thankfully less hectic, but still doesn't really teach you how to use your abilities properly. In single-player you can't get resurrected (obviously) so, instead, you have a certain amount of lives. Die and you can't use that character anymore and this continues until you run out of characters (i.e. lives).Now, on the other hand, Monaco has more than enough content and some missions should take you over 30 minutes to finish. They can certainly be fun while playing with  a group of friends.This little review does make it look like I hate it, but I really don't. I truly like this game, I just wish it was better on certain fronts, or maybe a bit more open to get rid of the chaos entirely. Make sure you give it a spin if you have a group of friends who you can communicate with, that should certainly help.[Rating: 80/100]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Monaco: What's Yours is mine is a 1-4 player co-op heist game, a lovely 8-bit game where you sneak through locations while trying to steal valuable goods, and is a game I cannot recommend more heartily.  This is one of the indie sensations like Fez and Bastion that were being talked about and were winning awards before the game was even released, so it would be CRIMINAL (pardon the pun) to ignore a game with as much accolades as Monaco.The gameplay revolves around each level being a bit like a puzzle.  There are guards, security cameras, alarms, motion detectors, and other things that you have to bypass in order to get the gold, documents, or money and escape.  Each player gets to choose a different thief that specializes in different things; every thief can do everything necessary to beat a mission, but the Lockpick can pick locks and safes much faster, the Pickpocket can gather gold much more safely than others, the Mole can break through walls, and so on.  Choosing your specialist comes down to playstyle more than necessity, which is very nice since that means your team can be built around what everyone likes most instead of needing to play this or that character.  This really lets people get into the game by picking the burglar that they think is coolest or most fun.Important note: By no means is this a game that depends on flawless execution.  The most fun is when the alarm inevitably goes off and you and your friends scramble trying to grab the money and still escape, with an army of guards chasing you the entire way.  These are the most enjoyable moments of the game, where everything has gone wrong and you're still desperately trying to get the money and escape while everyone is laughing and trying to hide and being shot at.  This is definitely a fun little party game, and though the later levels require a little planning, it truly is a great game to play with friends or family of any age.I cannot recommend this game higher as a co-op game for you and a few friends.  Buy it, bring a friend or two over if you have some controllers, and enjoy Monaco, where What's There is Yours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												This is a really good game.  It's a top down sneak game with a wide array of characters to choose from.  You play a few levels and it's really easy, and you think "oh, this'll be an easy 100%."Wrong.  There are over 30 levels to complete, and about halfway it starts to ramp up the difficulty.  Guards are everywhere, lasers are everywhere, trip lasers are everywhere, and then later all the lasers have shotguns on them (not kidding.)  Towards the end the difficulty is ramped up so high it's just brutal.But it's a good kind of difficulty.  You can't just barrel your way through the game and then get mad when it punishes you.  If you take things slow, plan out your course of action, then even the hardest levels are posssible.8/10There are some sneak elements that're missing but overall a very satisfying game.

content:

												Excerpt from the handbook of The Security Professionals Association of Monaco:"Dear future security officer, congratulations on choosing one of today's most exciting career opportunities in the Principality of Monaco. You are about to embark on an adventure unlike any other: guarding the wealth of some of the most powerful and famous people on the planet. Here are some useful guidelines to performing your job at the level of excellence and thoroughness that our customers have come to expect of us:- If you should face the possibility of dealing with an intruder, take a few seconds to make extra sure that it wasn't nothing. It was probably nothing.- If you are absolutely certain that you have spotted an intruder, but then lose track, don't feel too bad, somebody else has probably taken care of it.- If you should suddenly remember being in a firefight and losing sight of intruders mere moments ago - calm down. Go back to your post, and if you should see something again: remember rule #1.- Now for the most important rule: potted plants are sacred and must never be disturbed or looked at.- Do you think you saw somebody walk behind a potted plant? Maybe even four people? Do you think that you could find out for sure if you just, you know, looked at the plant? WELL TOUGH LUCK, DUMBASS, YOU HAD BETTER MADE ABSOLUTELY SURE FIRST SO GO BACK AND DO YOUR DUTY.- Somebody tried to hide behind a potted plant while you were in a firefight and you're absolutely 100% completely sure he is still there? FINE. SHOOT AT THE PLANT. See how you feel about it when we cut your paycheck, vacation and transfer you to guarding the basement toilets for the next 30 years, PLANTKILLER.- Also sacred? VENTS. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT MESS WITH THE VENTS. If an intruder is going inside a vent, DO NOT PURSUE. DO NOT SHOOT AT THE VENT. Do you know how to fix a vent? Cause I sure don't. SO DON'T ♥♥♥♥ING CAUSE ALL OF US TO SUFFOCATE BECAUSE YOU HAD TO PLAY THE HERO.- Finally, if you happen to shoot an intruder, do. not. touch. the. body. You probably didn't attend any biology classes so allow me to break it down for you: dead bodies carry HORRIBLE TERRIBLE DISEASES. Leave them exactly where they drop and return to your station immediately. Somebody better equipped to handle the situation than your plant-killing vent-shooting♥♥♥♥♥is surely going to come and take care of it. We have found that bodies have a tendency to disappear more quickly when left unattended.With these simple guidelines you should have a blast in your new job! In light of recent unexpected mortality spikes we hope that you understand that we had to revoke all life insurance policies for new employees."[[On a more serious note, if you have a bunch of friends to play then Monaco is a funny, challenging and surprisingly complex co-op heist game, featuring a nice soundtrack and multiple free expansions.]]

content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												This is a game that truly shines in the co-op multiplayer, especially while playing locally or on a LAN. Each level in this game starts out as Ocean's Eleven, but can quickly turn into Boondock Saints.  Success depends upon a combination of coordination and improvisation, as well as clever use of the distinct characters and their unique abilities. Single-player can also provide its own challenges, as you have fewer "tools" with your team of one.After three years of development, this is an indie game that exhibits a lot of polish. From the intuitive implemenation of stealth to the clever level design to the fast-paced music, it's easy to see why Monaco won multiple awards at the Independent Games Festival in 2010. It plays well with a keyboard or controller and with Steam Workshop, there is an endless amount of content, from tutorials to PvP arenas.Also: trading cards.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2013
												Monaco is a game that’s as much about thinking on your feet as it is about stealth and forward planning, and regardless of whether you’re after a fun co-op game for four people, or something to speedrun to impress people on YouTube, I daresay there’s something here for everyone thanks to its focus on sheer entertainment. It’s exquisitely pieced together in almost every way, it lets you play in a variety of different ways and challenges you to think outside the box, and I can’t imagine anyone that could fail to be taken in by its charms.Monaco is a fantastic and unique take on the stealth genre and a showcase of excellent design, and you should make it yours. Not getting your hands on this would be a crime.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												At first I didn't really 'get' this game or why it was so good. I didn't care about the co-op either, as I figured playing with random people wouldn't be great. Then I found myself playing it all weekend and absolutely loving it, and hugely enjoying co-op with random people as well.It seems really simple at first, but the game has a lot of depth. You start to realise how many options you have for dealing with the levels, and the levels go from the trivial opening ones to incredibly difficult end ones. The middle levels are wonderful and the later levels are a huge challenge. A good co-op team can help but isn't required.The people playing the game are properly into it and everyone seems to intuitively understand what each other is doing, and it's a lot of fun.Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Monaco is a great co-op dungeon run. Or maybe you could compare it favorably to Left 4 Dead. It's a great game.There's no accumulation of loot like you find in MMOs or ARPGs, but this is a feature, not a flaw. Since everyone starts equally, it's easier to pull people into a game at any given time. You don't have to worry about whether your character is too high a level or too low a level, or whether you have the "proper" gear. You just get get up to 4 people together and just do it.It has a forgiving "death" mode, much like Borderlands, Left 4 Dead, or Guild Wars 2. When playing with friends, if you are downed, you can be recovered by another player. As long as one person is still alive, the game continues!It also has several different modes of success. You can just try to complete the level. You can try to clean it out entirely. Or you can try to do both of the above against the clock. For the hardcore, speedruns may be their thing. For the more casual player, survival might be the challenge. And there are different versions/difficulties of each of the levels, so unlocking those is another potential goal. And of course there are "cheevos" through Steam for doing other silly things. So there's a lot to aim for with this game.The graphics are stylish, the music is perfect, and the dialogue witty. My only criticism is that it's a little hard to figure out the "ring" of indicators surrounding your character. Parsing that data is hard with all of the other visual distractions on the screen at any given time. But by the time you learn 'em, it's mostly moot. At that point you will probably have enough experience with the game not to need 'em too much.And the price? Cheap! I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Whats yours is mine, and whats on offer here is a simple concept, done really well, provides a lot of entertainment, and is all about the multiplayer.  Monaco flys under the radar for a lot of people as it isn't a big name title, and doesnt pretend to be, but the number of different ways you can play the game using different characters with different skills mean there is no right or wrong way to get through the game, although inevitably people will find their own style of play.  Playing with friends is where this excels.  Those moments when someone gets caught and dies in a really stupid place full of laser beams and guards and then trying to come in with a plan to create enough of a distraction for someone to get in and revive them is so much fun.  If you dont have this and see it on offer for under  £2, buy a few copies for your mates, and it will easily repay it with the entertainment time it gives you back.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Monaco is easily one of my favourite games in my big games library. A quirky stealth action, you take the role of 4 characters, at the start, The Locksmith, The Pickpocket, The Lookout and The Cleaner. Each with their own abilities, and hidden abilities, to aid themselves, or their team. You play through and unlock more characters each with their own unique abilites and ways to aid. Honestly this game is best played MP where it can get out of hand and chaotic, which to be honest is where the most fun is. Running from guards desperatly trying to revive your teammates while being careful that dog doesn't get to you, it's really enjoyable. If you are a completionist then best avoid this as to 100% you have to get 4 trophies, they are as followed: completed in SP, completed in MP, completed without dying (or if doing on MP none of you can die) and finally cleaning out the level, which you must do for EVERY level. Some of the later levels get ridiculously hard.So in summary I would definitly reccommend this game and you should buy it, especially because the Dev who made it is a really nice guy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Very fun game, alone or with friends. It's simple, yet complex at the same time- And each mission is unique, so you won't feel like you are repeating the same thing over and over again, and with each different class means a different way of finishing the mission! No matter your skill, It gets harder as you go along, so you're guaranteed to face a challenge at some point. As for faults, personally, if any, is going to have to be with Multiplayer. Anybody can join, beginners or advanced, so each time is different. But, it lacks challenge. A team-member can be reckless and set off all the guards and what not, or everyone can go off and do their own thing, and the mission can still be completed, I wish it could be more along the lines of, one wrong move and your entire mission will fail, hence forcing teamwork. Other than that, I'd give the game 4/5 stars.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												An absolutely fantastic game to play locally with 3 of your friends, though I can't quite get my head around why one of us was forced to use a keyboard and mouse rather than a 4th controller. The game's biggest strength is its simplicity; you get your choice of 4 characters (8 by the end) and each has one distinct function, with perhaps one other side function. You take your little team through numerous 3 or 4 level stages and try to steal as much stuff as you can, as fast as you can, while trying not to be seen. We were incredibly bad at it but still managed to finish the main campaign and have 12 hours of fun on a lazy Sunday doing it.Also, you revive your teammates by pressing against their dead bodies while your character makes a bunch of slurping noises. Just saying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is a must buy for such a low price! Easy to understand when you start off playing. A great combination of stealth play, tower heist and a 16 bit colourful retro theme. Plus the light piano music & french accents is like the cherry on top. Also a bird eye view setting.If you feel like stealing a bunch of valuable objects from buildings with plenty of security guards that you can either kill or make confused as hell, then you'll love this game.There's a choice of 4+ characters with distinct unique abilities to help disarm alarms, hack computers, unlock doors, break down walls, you name it! You can pick up weapons too (AK-47s, spanners, C9s) but I find that breaks the stealth mode you want to enjoy and should really be used if you have no other option.There are plenty of levels to play with character stories behind them. Co-op of up to 4 players is a great feature with so much more room for activities!Super fun, highly recommended 10/10

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Excerpt from the handbook of The Security Professionals Association of Monaco:"Dear future security officer, congratulations on choosing one of today's most exciting career opportunities in the Principality of Monaco. You are about to embark on an adventure unlike any other: guarding the wealth of some of the most powerful and famous people on the planet. Here are some useful guidelines to performing your job at the level of excellence and thoroughness that our customers have come to expect of us:- If you should face the possibility of dealing with an intruder, take a few seconds to make extra sure that it wasn't nothing. It was probably nothing.- If you are absolutely certain that you have spotted an intruder, but then lose track, don't feel too bad, somebody else has probably taken care of it.- If you should suddenly remember being in a firefight and losing sight of intruders mere moments ago - calm down. Go back to your post, and if you should see something again: remember rule #1.- Now for the most important rule: potted plants are sacred and must never be disturbed or looked at.- Do you think you saw somebody walk behind a potted plant? Maybe even four people? Do you think that you could find out for sure if you just, you know, looked at the plant? WELL TOUGH LUCK, DUMBASS, YOU HAD BETTER MADE ABSOLUTELY SURE FIRST SO GO BACK AND DO YOUR DUTY.- Somebody tried to hide behind a potted plant while you were in a firefight and you're absolutely 100% completely sure he is still there? FINE. SHOOT AT THE PLANT. See how you feel about it when we cut your paycheck, vacation and transfer you to guarding the basement toilets for the next 30 years, PLANTKILLER.- Also sacred? VENTS. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT MESS WITH THE VENTS. If an intruder is going inside a vent, DO NOT PURSUE. DO NOT SHOOT AT THE VENT. Do you know how to fix a vent? Cause I sure don't. SO DON'T ♥♥♥♥ING CAUSE ALL OF US TO SUFFOCATE BECAUSE YOU HAD TO PLAY THE HERO.- Finally, if you happen to shoot an intruder, do. not. touch. the. body. You probably didn't attend any biology classes so allow me to break it down for you: dead bodies carry HORRIBLE TERRIBLE DISEASES. Leave them exactly where they drop and return to your station immediately. Somebody better equipped to handle the situation than your plant-killing vent-shooting♥♥♥♥♥is surely going to come and take care of it. We have found that bodies have a tendency to disappear more quickly when left unattended.With these simple guidelines you should have a blast in your new job! In light of recent unexpected mortality spikes we hope that you understand that we had to revoke all life insurance policies for new employees."[[On a more serious note, if you have a bunch of friends to play then Monaco is a funny, challenging and surprisingly complex co-op heist game, featuring a nice soundtrack and multiple free expansions.]]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2013
												Monaco is a game that’s as much about thinking on your feet as it is about stealth and forward planning, and regardless of whether you’re after a fun co-op game for four people, or something to speedrun to impress people on YouTube, I daresay there’s something here for everyone thanks to its focus on sheer entertainment. It’s exquisitely pieced together in almost every way, it lets you play in a variety of different ways and challenges you to think outside the box, and I can’t imagine anyone that could fail to be taken in by its charms.Monaco is a fantastic and unique take on the stealth genre and a showcase of excellent design, and you should make it yours. Not getting your hands on this would be a crime.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												At first I didn't really 'get' this game or why it was so good. I didn't care about the co-op either, as I figured playing with random people wouldn't be great. Then I found myself playing it all weekend and absolutely loving it, and hugely enjoying co-op with random people as well.It seems really simple at first, but the game has a lot of depth. You start to realise how many options you have for dealing with the levels, and the levels go from the trivial opening ones to incredibly difficult end ones. The middle levels are wonderful and the later levels are a huge challenge. A good co-op team can help but isn't required.The people playing the game are properly into it and everyone seems to intuitively understand what each other is doing, and it's a lot of fun.Highly recommended!

												This game is almost 'Realistic' from a birds perspective. You can play as different escaped prisoners or people they free in the game. The Hacker is my favourite cause it can deactivate all the electronics for a short while where you walk close too. I Highly recommend to play this game with friends or people who know what they do with they Character and/or the level. You also see the spots like with a coloured perspective like in real life. I mean, when you have a closed door you can't see what's behind it even with the perspective. You can only see, what we also can see if we stand there. Also everyone can make hiding spots in the bushes on some maps to prevent that cops find them easily as they walk by. The weapon system and Equipment system is also a new sort of way to play, you get an extra item of the item you got by collecting money. In overall it's a game who wants to be sneaky, stealth, rich, demolishfull, a charmer or a codebreaker.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												What can I say. This game is a fun co-op puzzle game. It reminds me of Bonanzo Brothers, an old game from back in the day. Basically everyone is working together to steal something, and then make a get away. Each class brings something unique to the table. The story is great. What this game excels at though is the casual fun that is to be had with friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												Monaco is a top-down heist game where you choose one of four characters (with an additional four unlocked as the story progresses), break out of prison, and then with the help of the mysterious Gentleman, attempt to flee Monaco. The story is in two parts, first told from the perspective of the Locksmith over 17 levels, then retold by the Pickpocket in another 16. There's also a level builder, and you can download new levels to play in the Steam community workshop.I'd call this a Stealth game, but the stealth often decays into a mad dash to run out of sight of enemies or to make a mad dash away from the C4 you just placed to blow open a safe or wall or security guard. The background music is reminiscent of ragtime piano, and changes to suit the situation if you're spotted or set off alarms.It's good in single-player, but where Monaco truly shines is 4-player co-op.I've very much enjoyed this game, and it's on sale (50% off) at the moment. Go buy this game, because it's great. :3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												What a great investment. I expected kind of an action puzzle game but the game is far more than this. The whole setting is very atmospheric, prison break, bank heist, rescueing a fellow criminal from a mansion. There are so many things to interact with like light barriers, vents, computers to hack in, the breaker box in the wine cellar and of course the guards that are animated sooo funny. If this wasn't enough, you get kind of a gangster movie soundtrack of the silent film age. It fits perfectly! Everything in this games fits. The multiplayer matches with friends are awesome. The best experience is sitting in a room and hear everybody screaming when the alarm at the museum you're robbing goes off. You have to buy this game and play it hard. Hopefully it's cheaper on christmas holidays (steam plz :D) so we get more good players online.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Monaco is easily one of my favourite games in my big games library. A quirky stealth action, you take the role of 4 characters, at the start, The Locksmith, The Pickpocket, The Lookout and The Cleaner. Each with their own abilities, and hidden abilities, to aid themselves, or their team. You play through and unlock more characters each with their own unique abilites and ways to aid. Honestly this game is best played MP where it can get out of hand and chaotic, which to be honest is where the most fun is. Running from guards desperatly trying to revive your teammates while being careful that dog doesn't get to you, it's really enjoyable. If you are a completionist then best avoid this as to 100% you have to get 4 trophies, they are as followed: completed in SP, completed in MP, completed without dying (or if doing on MP none of you can die) and finally cleaning out the level, which you must do for EVERY level. Some of the later levels get ridiculously hard.So in summary I would definitly reccommend this game and you should buy it, especially because the Dev who made it is a really nice guy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												An enjoyably arcadey take on the criminal genre that embraces a larger emphasis on stealth than PAYDAY, but a more forgiving view on alerting enemies than Thief. The game contains a ream of both developer and custom-made content, with full Steam Workshop support. Good alone, spectacular with friends.Positives:+ Extremely entertaining, fluid, yet challenging gameplay+ A selection of classes that genuinely change the way you play+ A fun, arcadey graphics style that communicates information effectively+ Seemingly endless content, with four campaigns and Steam Workshop support for user created levels+ An easily usable level editor, containing all of the tiles, objects and tools used in the game.+ Easily-hosted serversNegatives:- Occasional sever connectivity issues- A large difficulty spike between the Pickpocket's Story and Fin campaign.- Lack of checkpoints can prove an irritationRating: 83%

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												I bought this game because it was on sale and looked fairly unique, but I wasn't expecting very much. I was wrong. This game is one of the best buys I've made during my time on steam. The trailer's don't necessarily do the graphics justice, which have really clear visuals, and a minimalistic, but aesthetically pleasing neon art style. The soundtrack is also killer, capturing the perfect tone. The gameplay is fantastic, akin to pacman with stealth, guns, and laser-rigged security systems. There is little in the way of tutorial, so you are left to experiment for yourself,but that works well for this for this game, which has you balance careful planning, against quick thinking and resourcefulness for when things go wrong. The plot was also pretty fresh, while nodding to tropes within the heist genre. The game offers a lot of replayability too, as though the single player is fun and carries the game by itself, the multiplayer enables you to play with others to try and try to grab everything and get out as fast as possible. In addition to this, the community is pretty good, and new levels are often being made. Of course, no game is perfect, and if I had to say something, it would be that though the plot was great, it was advanced sparingly from mission to mission. If story is what you look for in a game, this may not be the game for you. Also, although you don't have to collect every coin to "win" a mission, if the coins are ignored some missions lose a lot of challenge, especially as on some earlier missions the number of lives you have is fairly generous. However, there are a lot of levels (3 parallel campaigns, with a 4th coming out soon, as well as zombie mode), so this would only bother those exceptionally impatient people who can't wait to unlock the later levels, which are extraordinarily challenging, even if you don't collect the coins!I would definitely give this game a 10/10 as it stands, and am very excited to play the new content which is coming out this year

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												In short, this game is about Heist. Get in, Rob, Get Out.It's long after I played Monaco with my friends (4 players Co-Op of course, that was a blast!)I decided to give a review, so apologize for any things I may forgot to mention below :By far, Monaco as an Indie game has great, solid, satisfying Coop experience. Team up with four players and break through buildings to sweep all shiny things you see. And four players can wreak havoc entire building, alerting every guards to chase you down. It's all the hilarous things popping out at every moment. One small misstep and the place will turn into chaos.Gameplay, Characters : You are a robber who steal stuffs in the city of Monaco. Like other heist games, this game requires avoiding guards patrolling here and there, stealing things, open doors, and hide in bushes. When played single player, this game have several lives which when the one you chose die, other characters show up to be picked again. So in total there are 8 characters, meaning you have 8 lives to do the single player campaign (Which I will say quite easy to do just a run, but not when doing a perfect one). Multiplayer, this is where the fun comes from. Up to four players, at the same time sneaking into a building filled with psychopath guards (there're psycho doctors too, hope this game doesn't change your perception), lasers, and... if I remember correctly, there are cats and dogs too, meowing and barking to alert the psychos. Four players, I have to admit, is less strategic than single player, if not pre-planned first. One player can cause havoc in one section, while others, panicking by the alerts, cause much more chaos and the whole place is about hit & run till you cut off from the guard's sight or die. And that's where the fun lies, saving your dead friend while being chased and shot by guards.Characters, there are 8 total characters to play with, 4 starting characters each with unique abilities. One can open locks fast, one can seek out guards on the map, one can loot coins automatically, and else. They're fun in their own ways.Controls, Mechanics, AIs : Pretty solid, and simple controls to handle. Only WASD to move and a mouse to aim & shoot the baddies along the way. Weapons are also fun to play with, shotgun can kill multiple enemies, a bomb can blow up a place in certain radius, health kit can restore half of your life upon use, and tranquilizer to make enemies sleep. Mechanics are pretty good and well-thought. You can plan a whole stealthy, sneaky robbery, or do an all-out rampage, taking everything in the path while escaping as soon as possible. AIs are also creative, chasing you down all the way until you die, or you can sneak behind them, leaving question marks along the way.Levels, Difficulties, Maps : Very creative, and the levels are designed in a way that you might be involved in a heist film. Hide into a bush, getting sneaky, turn off the lasers and lights. There are so many things to play with before the robbery happens and the grand escape begins. Difficulty-wise, the pacing is perfect for a heist game. While I did have to retry a few times at the first act, after knowing the mechanics of the AI, the rest of the act is about executing and improving your heist skills.Story : I didn't read the story though, I skipped all the dialogues, so yeah I'll skip this one. But it's quite interesting and easy to pick-up.Music : Loved the theme song, and the Discotheque Rouge (If I'm not wrong) level. Musics are catchy like actual heist movies, and they are French-themed, so they're unique in French ways. Cons : So far haven't found any cons, only that the difficulty curve at the start is probably a bit high (I haven't played any heist games, so that should be counted as a factor too)Tl;dr, get this game with your other 3 friends. Break into buildings, one by one and make chaos all over Monaco! 100% Fun and laughter guaranteed!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												If you enjoy 2D, retro-style games, you will love Monaco. It truly shines as a cooperative experience.You can go through most of the story completely solo (and at times it may be easier for some levels), and the game offers an offline/online feature that is very well integrated. Levels you have unlocked will have a marker indicating open lobby sessions, making it easier to join up for cooperative play. The steam workshop also has fantastic mods, including two CRITICAL tutorials that everyone should go through to get a good feel for the game. The jewel store from PAYDAY 2 is a particularly exciting one. Replayability just for these mods is endless.The aesthetics are great, and the fog of war mechanic is beautifully-executed: there will be a blueprint for each level (including floors), and you will only be able to see the details of your character's field of vision, the rest will remain gray. You can see nearby footsteps of your enemies, but require the Lookout character for constant enemy awareness. This makes for intense gameplay when you are in one area of the map and die, while your other teammates are on the other side, all running away from guards.The layout is still very friendly as your objectives will be indicated by large trophies on the map, and there usually be many signs on the ground to give you directions. The "action" timer is given by a small circle that fills up for everything you may have to do, from opening a window to unlocking a door so you can go into the urinal and pee (yes, there is an animation for peeing).The game incorporates an "ammo" system for whatever active item you have equipped (ex: C4, shotgun, smoke grenade, etc) that gives you +1 whenever you collect 10 of the yellow collectibles. While you share the total team score with your party at the end, your specific ammo count is individual, so you may have to decide who collects the resources if they are running low.Each character class comes with different skills and responsiblities, making for very diverse gameplay (and high replayability).Very charming cooperative (initally) game. (There are PvP modes lol)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Whats yours is mine, and whats on offer here is a simple concept, done really well, provides a lot of entertainment, and is all about the multiplayer.  Monaco flys under the radar for a lot of people as it isn't a big name title, and doesnt pretend to be, but the number of different ways you can play the game using different characters with different skills mean there is no right or wrong way to get through the game, although inevitably people will find their own style of play.  Playing with friends is where this excels.  Those moments when someone gets caught and dies in a really stupid place full of laser beams and guards and then trying to come in with a plan to create enough of a distraction for someone to get in and revive them is so much fun.  If you dont have this and see it on offer for under  £2, buy a few copies for your mates, and it will easily repay it with the entertainment time it gives you back.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Monaco: What's Yours is mine is a 1-4 player co-op heist game, a lovely 8-bit game where you sneak through locations while trying to steal valuable goods, and is a game I cannot recommend more heartily.  This is one of the indie sensations like Fez and Bastion that were being talked about and were winning awards before the game was even released, so it would be CRIMINAL (pardon the pun) to ignore a game with as much accolades as Monaco.The gameplay revolves around each level being a bit like a puzzle.  There are guards, security cameras, alarms, motion detectors, and other things that you have to bypass in order to get the gold, documents, or money and escape.  Each player gets to choose a different thief that specializes in different things; every thief can do everything necessary to beat a mission, but the Lockpick can pick locks and safes much faster, the Pickpocket can gather gold much more safely than others, the Mole can break through walls, and so on.  Choosing your specialist comes down to playstyle more than necessity, which is very nice since that means your team can be built around what everyone likes most instead of needing to play this or that character.  This really lets people get into the game by picking the burglar that they think is coolest or most fun.Important note: By no means is this a game that depends on flawless execution.  The most fun is when the alarm inevitably goes off and you and your friends scramble trying to grab the money and still escape, with an army of guards chasing you the entire way.  These are the most enjoyable moments of the game, where everything has gone wrong and you're still desperately trying to get the money and escape while everyone is laughing and trying to hide and being shot at.  This is definitely a fun little party game, and though the later levels require a little planning, it truly is a great game to play with friends or family of any age.I cannot recommend this game higher as a co-op game for you and a few friends.  Buy it, bring a friend or two over if you have some controllers, and enjoy Monaco, where What's There is Yours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Monaco is easily one of my favourite games in my big games library. A quirky stealth action, you take the role of 4 characters, at the start, The Locksmith, The Pickpocket, The Lookout and The Cleaner. Each with their own abilities, and hidden abilities, to aid themselves, or their team. You play through and unlock more characters each with their own unique abilites and ways to aid. Honestly this game is best played MP where it can get out of hand and chaotic, which to be honest is where the most fun is. Running from guards desperatly trying to revive your teammates while being careful that dog doesn't get to you, it's really enjoyable. If you are a completionist then best avoid this as to 100% you have to get 4 trophies, they are as followed: completed in SP, completed in MP, completed without dying (or if doing on MP none of you can die) and finally cleaning out the level, which you must do for EVERY level. Some of the later levels get ridiculously hard.So in summary I would definitly reccommend this game and you should buy it, especially because the Dev who made it is a really nice guy.

												Monaco is the first game I’ve played that truly nails the feeling of the heist, with enough traps, items, and different characters that co-op play with friends should be a staple of your online activity for the months to come. However, the over-long campaign is a chore when played solo, especially when the story suffers as a result. If you and your friends are looking for a new game to play together, Monaco is a no-brainer. But playing through Monaco by yourself, or leaving your enjoyment up to groups of strangers, can yield uneven results.

												This game is a pleasure to play. Four player co-op itself is a strong selling point for a game; adding a terrific art style and a dynamic soundtrack makes this game all the more appealing. What makes this game a must-have, though? The fight-or-flight gameplay style. You can sneak your way through, looting every coin and dodging every guard, or you can dive in all Tally-HO! into the action, sprinting down corridors and peppering security with bullets in a frantic escape. The choice is yours.Thumbs up!

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I wasn't sure what to expect from Monaco, whether it would be more arcade or more realistic. And I've come to the conclusion it's a little bit of both.When you open the game, the menu itself moves very nicely, with graphics flowing in the background. Right off the bat, there are multiple gamemode options. I dove right into “Campaign” mode, and, like many other games, it showed me the first mission I could complete in color, and all the others were grayed out. However, what I really liked about playing Monaco's campaign, is that I could join/start a lobby, have up to three other people with me, and could stay in that lobby and keep selecting episodes instead of having to join a new lobby for each episode. The gameplay itself is very nice. You start on the first episode by choosing one of four characters, each with their own perk. As you progress through levels, you gain more characters. The game loads very quickly, after you depart from the neat lobby menu of changing options (which is always fun). It is a top-down game, but there are obviously good reasons for that. On the top, directions will be given as to what you have to do, so that it's never confusing, and the goal is to sneak past the police/guards to get to the object the heist was started for and all the spare money along the way. There are weapons to pick up from time to time, but I found that running away from guards and hiding in a room for a few seconds keeps them off your scent.Pros:Menus move very smoothly.The graphics, being a top-down game, are pretty decent.The objectives are always clear.You can stay in the same lobby for as many levels as you choose.All campaign levels can be completed in either singleplayer or multiplayer.The controller support is amazing, and I actually prefer to use the controller.There's Steam Workshop to download new levels to play.It's local co-op too, so it's good for a party with friends if you have more than one controller.Cons:Gun reloading is very obnoxious. It shouldn't take 10 seconds for one bullet to reload.The co-op community is not as large as I had hoped.Guards are almost too easy to get past.So, basically, I had a lot of fun playing this game, though I would recommend getting it on sale.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
What´s this game about?This game is a incredible top-down stealth game with big, open levels, interesting characters with various abilities and weaknesses, each proposing a different playstyle. You break into art galleries, embassys, police headquarters, ships, prisons (...), each level featuring an interesting combination of surveillance cameras, lasers, handprint scanners, locked doors, ventilation shafts, bushes or plants to hide in, PCs and power outlets to inject viruses, and inattentive guards carrying special keys. (...) How much content/replayability?There is a vast amount of dev-made levels, including little text-based briefings. You can replay a level again and again, a different character selection most certainly leading to a entirely different game expierence. It is great fun to collect all coins scattered through the levels ("clean out"), which acts +/- as a optional sidequest.Additional:And then there is the Steam workshop....And then there is Multiplayer, which is almost a game on its own, including 4-player support.And then there are gadgets, like shotguns, crossbows with tranquillizer darts, medikits, smoke bombs, C4 (...) which you obtain by collecting coins.SO: Buy this game if you like stealth, Co-Op action/voicechat chaos, good timing, tactical thinking and top-down games.I give it a 9/10. Excellent indie game with balanced and distinct characters, very good replayability, 4-Player Co-Op Support and the Steam Workshop offering even more old rich men to loot.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Monaco is a very fun game: you can play in singleplayer mode as well with up to 3 friends using one among 8 characters with different special skills (yes, it's much more fun playing with friends). Every level is pretty much unique and you can approach at it in many different ways, according to the members of your party. Obviously the stealthier the better. At the end of every level your score is based upon the time you spent finishing the level (that is catching the main objectives) to which will be added a penalty that will be as big as he coins you missed during the level.Artistically speaking, we're dealing with a jewel: your screen will be invaded by any sort of color and the retro style is something simply beatiful.Base gameplay is already various, but it's additionally enhanced by the presence of the zombie mode which is very difficult, even though I haven't played very much.In addition to what I've already written, there are many interesting community levels which can help you learn the basics of the classes and many tricks.In the end: I absolutely recommend this game because it's simply one of the best and deep coop experiences you can find.10/10

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
An indie coop heist game.Amazingly fun to play in coop with friends online or on a single screen, though it requires X360 gamepads for other players (max 4 players either on- or offline). Great challenge when going solo, especially with the additional task of collecting all the loot. The game may look simple at first, but give it some time and you should find it interestingly challenging. Definitely for people who like to max out the levels. There are eight characters to choose from (4 during the first missions); each has its advantages and drawbacks, thus each of them requires a different approach and strategies, but in coop they complement each other. Time spent on each level can be compared with other players via the built-in leaderboards. Not to mention the great, full of twists story, the built-in map editor (steam workshop), good humour (guards' voices), good replay value, additional zombie mode and the free expansion which closes the story. There are a couple of flaws, but they are outnumbered by the sheer fun when playing this. It seems like the developers really loved creating this gem. At least that's what I felt while playing it. Vous allez adorer, monsieur

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Hands down, the best game I have ever experienced. Though it was made in 2009 it has graphical capabilities akin to next-gen consoles. The narrative storytelling seems real, beautiful, as Microsoft Sam always does. I feel as though I need to help the Rats or my purpose in life will never be fulfilled the Rats need me, and I need the Rats. I will never put this game down, the sheer heavenly, awe-inspiring, near-♥♥♥♥♥♥ic experience this game gives you is like nothing else I have ever seen. Beware: this game will, 100%, eat away hours, days, months and eventually years of your life as the lifelike physics bamboozle you thank you Invent4 Entertainment you are all Gods and will live in my unworthy, mortal heart forever. Simply the greatest game developers that have made the best games the have ever existed. I salute you. Well, now my heart-filled intro is over, I really need to stress how good this game is. The developers tease you greatly with the USP (Unique Selling Points) on the store page and they are: Revel in your success as the cat meets a violent demise in any number of humorous ways at the hands of Bad Rats... Comic cartoon violence and cartoon blood Realistic physics simulation 10 Specialist Rats, anxious for revenge 11 different and bloody deaths for cats 10 other functional objects to help you 44 Maps, from easy to very hard Internet and local records Original, cartoon styled characters Challenge your creativity, intelligence and logic Unlock all the Steam Achievements But that's not all, there is a spiritual side to this game that I don't think even the developers know they implemented a oneness with the Gods. While you can have fun earning every achievement each one unlocking a sense of pleasure more than you can ever experience with any other game no any other moment in you're entire life. Each puzzle is an embodiment of pure culture and art. Art made by Rube Goldberg-Esq physics and complex solutions. This game, oh, this game, I really cannot say enough about it I love this game. I can't say it enough I love this game, and so will you. You will succumb to the awesomeness of this game the, the thorough and overall righteousness of this experience. If you don't own Bad Rats, you have not lived a full and proper life in anyone's eyes. I would rate this 11/10 if I could. While writing this, I am currently crying all over my keyboard due to the beauty of this game, my keyboard is now soaked and some keys don't seem to be working. I sob because not everybody owns this game and that means they have never, ever, been truly happy. I love you, Invent4 entertainment, for developing this game, and I also love and cherish you, Strategy First for, on the great day of the 20th of July 2009, publishing this game and blessing this small, humble world with the holy, out-of-this world, pure greatness that is the one and only: Bad Rats. Now, to Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge. People think that this is the exact same as the original, but it isn't. It has all the things that the Godly original had, the Nobel-prize worthy 4:3 screen mode so beautiful that there was no need for 16:9 and not to mention the fact you can play in a 1240 PX resolution. The technological world, no, the entire world, all the worlds the universe did not foresee the striking difference 1240 PX game play has against the standard 1280. But, Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge is something perfect, people said Braid was "The Perfect Game" but then they played Bad Rats said it was Godly and then realized the power of Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge it has something that neither science nor religion can explain. Something only a unknown, un-comprehendable higher power can give a reason for, a true explanation. The Rats' Revenge seems to be able to unite everybody and has been documented to have been able to end wars, and be the first real, legitimate sign of world peace being achievable. In the great war of 2009. the US government, CIA, and FBI created a game capable of sending waves of peace across the world. Everyone who played it was happier than they had ever been, and realized the was no reason for fighting when you had Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge. No other game or other form of media had been able to achieve this, to give this amazing degree of hope to a mortal world plagued by war. The game was a message from God, a holy beckoning that has ultimately saved the world from utter destruction. The game has saved all of us, and that is why we need to pay our respects to it. I say that this day, the 1st of November, after the day of the devil Halloween should be Bad Rats day, to show that we are past the evil spirits that once doomed us because of this one, singular, 300MB piece of pure glory. On this day, the world will pray for the Rats and show non-believers what this game really is, by sending copies to everyone we know. This is why it is on sale, it is holy. 10/10

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
Monaco is all about the grand heists. Robbing casinos, banks, palaces, hotels and escaping with everything that's shiny. A series of levels in which you steal all the goodies then make a quick run for the nearest exit. Monaco is truly a unique take on the "heist" genre. If you give it half a chance and more than just a couple of challenging hours then you just might find a hidden gem that is more enjoyable and challenging than many other AAA games that are out there right now.Monaco may initially be written off as just a bare-bones 2D top-down view game, boring when played alone. But I did. And it was great. To me this title is very underrated. If you go deeper into the gameplay and the storyline that stretches across multiple levels, you'll find a game that's both intriguing and amusing. Monaco follows a crew of misfits, with each individual bringing a set of shady abilities to the table. They're all in it for the long con. The player gets to control any one of them on each level, and as they are each and all very different, so is the manner, tempo, and style by which you can play. Monaco has all the characteristics of a good PC heist game:Planning and strategy is crucial every step of the way; if you just jump into a room full of guards you are sure to die in the ensuing chaos. There are many tools of the trade provided however, and it's important to use them carefully. Monaco grows on you the more you come to terms with how simple yet challenging the game mechanics work.Level design is logical, meaningful, and often intimidating. But the game does a good job of balancing skill, strategy and luck for the player. There are often several methods of reaching the objective within a given level. This goes hand in hand with the various different characters within the game, and I do mean everyone. Monaco takes every one of them into account and still (perhaps) manages to balance the challenge for each different style of play. I myself preferred to play as the Gentleman. PC (KB+M) controls are simple, sharp and manageable. Keyboard remapping is also available, but for some reason does not work in the menus. The character you control is always in your focal point as this is a top-down view game; there should be no blaming the camera for any mistakes you make here. The in-game HUD is also minimal and clear on objectives and whatever else needs to be known.  AI is a little difficult to explain here, but like most games the more you play Monaco the easier it is to understand and adapt. The key is in avoiding detection; the longer you are out in plain view of guards and civilians the more suspicion you draw. This suspicion is based on line of sight; but unlike how it is often very difficult to know where guards are and how they will see you in FPS or third-person games, the top-down strategic view here makes things much easier for you to act and react. This level of control really makes you understand that if something does go wrong, then only you are to blame.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												With a colorful artstyle and a chaotic nature, this is a game where you seem not to know what is going on at any moment in time. Yes, I am here reviewing yet another four-person co-opertative. This is a very strange type of game through concept, but achieves enjoyment through being very chaotic, escpcially when all four players are present for the experience. There are multiple characters to play as, with each one having a special ability that assist the team in one way or another. You can play through the game either through the stealth means or running through it, getting spotted by the security will peforming said action. This video game was specifcally taliored for co-opertative, as having multiple individuals in the game at once is benefital to the success of the operation. If you are trying to play this without being spotted, it is very difficult, with their being a mass amount of security officer and civilans present on each level. There are ways to avoid said obstacles, such as vents and other means of traveling around. The gameplay is enjoyable, with teamwork infused into multiple actions, such as if a teammate was killed you will need to go to revive them and can not proceed without doing so. So, would I recommend Monaco, yes, as it is an enjoyable co-operative experience.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												My friend bought me this game and I have never sat down and tried to play it seriously, so I am only writing this at his request. I don't really get it.I say that with a lot of games. And usually it's because I don't have the patience and like to blame other things for my own faults. I've only played it multiplayer, and it felt like there was no real strategy. My friends and I would all pick whatever characters ( I was the Mole because he was by far the coolest ) and would pretty much just run about the stage doing whatever. We were probably only on the default difficulty, and obviously weren't going for any high scores, yet nothing was really stopping us. We would waltz right into the building or whatever, grab the money, knock a few people out, die, get revived, and then eventually progress through the level and win. I never felt like I was supposedly to play differently. It almost felt like I didn't even need to, because if I could play sloppy like this, why waste my time trying to be smart and stealthy?I'm a bit biased against the game, because I feel like I never really gave it a chance. I think if you have the patience to try and play it strategically then it could be interesting. I do think it's a relatively original concept, so it has that going for it. Plus, everyone speaks French so that's kinda cool.Pretty colours / 10.

content:
Posted: February 12
												Lead a gang of misanthropic professional thieves through a string of heists in Monaco: What’s yours is mine, an exciting stealth-based action game with retro graphics. Each professional in your gang has their own specialty and it’s up to you to use the right man (or woman) for the job.While Monaco is definitely playable solo (for some of the missions) its real strength lies in multiplayer where you are able to combine up to 4 various professionals’ talents to subdue guards, thwart security systems, and steal everything in sight. The game is also more forgiving in multiplayer, allowing you to resuscitate your comrades if they fall in the line of duty. If you’re feeling unchallenged, there’s also a level editor that allows for a wide variety of custom-made mission that you can make and share with others.As of February 2017, this game’s online community has died off quite a bit, so if you’re planning on picking up this title I would recommend getting 2-3 friends to tag along. Monaco is loads of fun with the right group.
